Subject: An okay-ish attempt but written with pure intention
Review: Let 1000 better writers than Chetan Bhagat get released and published in India but whenever the book by the Superstar himself releases, the pre-booking breaks all the records. I can never resist buying his book as soon as the pre-order is opened for all the readers. Chetan Bhagat's 8th book overall and categorically, 2nd non-fictional book released 2 days back named "Making India Awesome". Chetan Bhagat never does a big launch and marketing tactics for his non-fictional books. He somewhere believes that people concerned with the growth of nation and having love for the country will definitely purchase a book based upon the idea of how to make it the Superpower. But without any fanfare too, the fans like me get to know about his book release.  "Making India Awesome" is Chetan Bhagat's attempt of sharing essays and columns he have written on nation time to time and explaining the complex issues in the easiest language possible. It is definitely in the lines of his first non-fictional book, "What Young India Wants?" but here, he is not that biased  towards parties the way he was in the former. Still, his love for Narendra Modi and BJP was evident in few sentences. The intention of the book can be clearly understood right from the first chapter itself. Chetan wants the nation to improve and therefore, he discusses ideas on many issues about how they can be resolved with whatever more or less knowledge he had regarding the same.  He have divided the book in four different parts- Awesome Governance, Awesome Equality, Awesome Society and Awesome Resources. Accordingly, he have discussed points like politics, economy, societal values, women's right, gay rights, minority rights and the transformation youth can bring to the nation. This 176-pages book is a light-read and you will find an urge of having an opinion on all the issues after you will end up reading the book. You will want to have an angle in your life for the nation too rather than only blaming the government, ministers and the whole system.  But there's a big problem with the ideas and solutions Chetan Bhagat have provided. The most of them are meant for the government and Prime Minister. The book is mainly like an open letter to Narendra Modi than to the youths of India. The book has been projected as if it's written for us on how to bring glory to the nation at personal level but it's more about how government can improve various things. He have discussed points on how even we can bring the change but even those points aren't much effective except few which are literally possible. I wish if Chetan Bhagat could have been little more sensible in putting up the solutions as some of them are really very silly to even think. I would give this pure effort 3.5* out of 5. Go For It! Thanks. ABHILASH RUHELA - VEERU!!!

Subject: Gives a general perception of India
Review: When I read the first few chapters of this book, I thought he is going to talk about politics all throughout. However, I was proved wrong. In fact, he covers a diverse set of topics ranging from politics to economy, from welfare to youth and beyond. Bhagat provides few examples where Indians have displayed lackluster character and imposing attitude. He cites few news-makers as a leverage to investigate the problems that society is facing, while suggesting policy makers and masses how to bring in changes in order to "make India awesome". Readers may have a different view, but, as someone who lived overseas for many years, I bought this book because I want to know more about India.

Subject: Good book, but by no sense awesome
Review: Good book, but by no sense awesome. Chetan Bhagat writes in this book in a manner as if he is speaking on a public platform/ forum , but then that has always been his style.The book is essential for Group discussions and for those candidates who have mentioned "Current Affairs" as a hobby.It does give you a better view of some of the issues you find in India and the tone used by the author is clear, cool and more mature than the generally unaware Indian.Read it, you may not love it, but you may like it surely.

Subject: A good must-read book for all
Review: Beautiful language... easy to understand.  His observations and foresight are quiet amazing, though I cannot agree with some of his views about the way forward and backward hindus' perspective towards political parties and politicians as well.  I liked most his categorisation of people on the basis of their enthusiasm towards day-to-day political and social developments taking place in our country.  Overall a must-read book.

Subject: Narendra Modi should take this book to heart and take actions suggested in this book!
Review: Excellent book covering key issues of modern India with lots good suggestions. The book may be a collection of essays published by the author in ToI. But that what makes the book so great. If you care about India or criticizing India and its politics, it is a must read. I have been visiting India for the past 5 years for volunteer service; I can relate to each and every issue Chetan Bhagat has covered so nicely. Very inspiring book for action oriented global citizens. It is an easy read with a no nonsense approach. I will be giving this book to many people as a gift.

Subject: Nice book
Review: Great book.Topics :Fighting corruption is not restricted to naming and shaming a few corrupt officials. If we think it is okay to cheat in exams, lie to a ticket collector in the train about our kids’ ages and pay a bit of money to avoid a big traffic fine, then at some level we clearly don’t care about eliminating corruption all that much. At best, we hate the politician who gets to steal (while we don’t).The average Indian anywhere in the country is looking for a better quality of life, a certain amount of hope and security and the freedom to make personal choices. The issues that really matter to us are the same. Differences exist, but they don’t run as deep as our politicians would have us believe….This similarity of aspirations, at a fundamental level, is what gives me hopeIf we really want them to ‘Make in India’, the government has to let go. Keep business rules, but align them with international standards. Get the government out of business….The current finance minister may be investor-friendly. The next one may not. If I have invested money in India, how can I be sure the new guy won’t come after me with a stick?Quite frankly, we have some way to go in achieving awesome levels. We still have Section 377, a legacy of the Victorian age, which criminalizes gay sex, a law so regressive, only a few orthodox religious states around the world have it today. We still don’t treat our women right, and often deny them rights without even realizing it. And every now and then, the fear of communalism and actual violence against religious minorities makes them feel unsafe.But mot of the things are like copy pasted from political magazines or news papers

To me that is an achievement for the author.  You cannot,  in fact,  need not give solutions to all the problems.  If you can make people think seriously about the problem you have won half of the battle.  Once the problem and a need for a solution is acknowledged, the quest for the solutions would begin. Subject: Balderdash
Review: The title of the review is one I doubt Mr.Bhagat will be able to pronounce at one go. I suppose contemplating any words longer than two syllables will make Mr. Bhagat's brain explode in superb technicolor.Calling this a 'book of ideas' or 'essays' is a bit of a stretch, since the essays read like they were written for a fourth (okay, I'll be generous - fifth) grade writing competition. But far be it for me to say that Mr. Bhagat is not an expert on anything. He is an expert on the non-sequitur and the strawman argument. For example, in one chapter he says that "until we see graft and tax evasion as a problem, and start to truly care about them, politicians will not change." Indeed, Mr. Bhagat, it is only a Bollywood-style emotional epiphany that is missing for us Indians to solve the problem of corruption! We just need to "care more"! The problems are not really structural, a result of complex regulation and the lack of simple legal and identity requirements in business transactions! The fact is, we just don't have the right "feelings" about this whole corruption business!And on and on. The book was a gift, and I can't wholly complain that it was a useless one. On days I felt bad about myself, this book served as an amazing pick-me-up. Why, I thought, leafing through the pages, here is an idiot who is willing to advertise the fact in print. I always closed it all cheered up.

All typical and known formula like change your attitude, develop discipline, concentrate on your individual contribution and attempts to clarify some social issues. Then, are they convincing and influential? The book fails to do that. The book lacks influential power. No topic is discussed in depth with full potential. Gender equality, you need to talk in details about stress on women working from 8 to 6 and its effect on individual family and combined effect on social condition of the nation. Also its adverse effect on health (read hormones) and child development who are future of the nation.There are many other topic which need to be detailed, for example, involvement of educated people in traditional agriculture which is backbone of the country, survival and improvement of the rural life, adverse effects of newer technologies, maintenance of environment.
